data.text: What is the neurotransmitter that motor neurons use to 'tell' skeletal muscles to contract?
You are examining cardiac muscle cells under the microscope. The term 'sarcolemma' refers to the plasma membrane of these cells.
During the initial phase of intense muscle contraction, which pathway is primarily responsible for rapidly regenerating ATP?
data.answer: Direct phosphorylation of ADP by creatine phosphate
choices: Direct phosphorylation of ADP by creatine phosphate

data.text: What is the neuromuscular junction composed of?
data.answer: Both part of a neuron (axon terminals) and part of a muscle cell (junctional folds)
choices: Only part of a neuron (axon terminals)
Only part of a muscle cell (junctional folds)
Both part of a neuron (axon terminals) and part of a muscle cell (junctional folds)
Neither part of a neuron nor part of a muscle cell

data.text: What is the main factor that influences whether a muscle fiber is slow oxidative, fast oxidative, or fast glycolytic?
In a cellular anatomy study, you encounter a segment of a myofibril that is described as the contractile unit. What is this segment called?
While investigating the role of muscles in the body, you find a tissue that can extend or stretch, even beyond its resting length. What is the term for this characteristic?
In a clinical setting, you find out that DMD patients may experience tears in their fragile sarcolemma during muscle contraction, allowing entry of excess Ca2+ and damaging contractile fibers.
In a molecular biology study, you discover that the central thick filaments in a sarcomere, containing myosin, extend the entire length of the A band.
Once initiated, is the action potential stoppable?
What is a motor unit?
data.answer: A motor neuron and all the muscle fibers it innervates.
choices: A motor neuron and all the muscle fibers it innervates.
The smallest contractile unit of a muscle fiber.

data.text: As part of your anatomy study, you are examining the cytoplasm of a muscle cell. What unique components are found in the sarcoplasm of a muscle cell?
What is the main difference between isotonic and isometric contractions?
data.answer: Isotonic contractions involve muscle shortening, while isometric contractions do not.
choices: Isotonic contractions involve muscle shortening, while isometric contractions do not.
Isometric contractions involve muscle shortening, while isotonic contractions do not.
Both involve muscle shortening, but at different rates.

data.text: What is the main advantage of the anaerobic glycolysis pathway in providing ATP during intense muscle activity?

As part of your medical studies, you come across a patient who exhibits muscle enlargement initially, followed by atrophy and degeneration of muscle fibers. What term would best describe this condition?
You are studying muscle contraction models. What is the smallest contractile unit of a muscle fiber?
You are studying the myosin molecule. What is the structure formed by the heavy chains of myosin?
Which chemical changes are associated with muscle fatigue?
data.answer: Decreased glycogen and increased inorganic phosphate
choices: Decreased glycogen and increased inorganic phosphate
Elevated lactic acid levels and increased Na1
Rise in pH and reduced potassium levels

data.text: In a physiological study, you observe muscle cells generating heat as they contract. This process plays a role in maintaining normal body temperature.
What is the main role of Excess Postexercise Oxygen Consumption (EPOC) in muscle recovery?
In a physiology lab, you are studying the structures that regulate muscle contraction. Which organelle stores and releases calcium ions, providing the final 'go' signal for contraction?
A patient is experiencing sustained contractions in a particular muscle. Which type of muscle tissue is most likely involved?
You are observing a muscle's origin and insertion during contraction. The movable bone, the muscle’s insertion, moves toward the immovable or less movable bone, the muscle’s origin.

As part of a clinical investigation, you find that smooth muscle in the walls of blood vessels helps maintain blood pressure by rhythmically beating. This function contributes to the movement of blood through the body.
Which type of muscle fiber is best suited for short-term, rapid, intense movements?
You are analyzing muscle tissue samples in the lab. What characteristic would help you identify skeletal muscle cells?
In a neuromuscular physiology class, you learn that the T tubules are continuations of the sarcolemma, conducting impulses to the deepest regions of the muscle cell and every sarcomere.
While examining the internal structure of a muscle, you come across a rodlike contractile element that occupies most of the muscle cell volume. What is this structure?
What enzyme terminates the effects of acetylcholine (ACh) in the synaptic cleft?
What is the role of calcium ions in muscle cell contraction?
data.answer: Calcium ions trigger the exposure of myosin-binding sites on actin.
choices: Calcium ions directly bind to actin.
Calcium ions promote the binding of tropomyosin to actin.
Calcium ions cause cross bridge detachment.
Calcium ions trigger the exposure of myosin-binding sites on actin.

data.text: What is muscle tone?
data.answer: The slight, continuous contraction of muscles.
choices: The phenomenon of muscles remaining completely relaxed.
The slight, continuous contraction of muscles.
The maximum force a muscle can produce.

data.text: In a research project focused on muscle contraction signaling, you discover that at the triads, membrane-spanning proteins from the T tubules and SR link together across the gap between the two membranes. What is the role of the protruding integral proteins of the T tubule in this context?
What is a muscle twitch?
data.answer: The response of a muscle to a single stimulation.
choices: The response of a muscle to a single stimulation.
The continuous contraction of a muscle.
The relaxation phase of muscle contraction.
The force exerted by a muscle during maximal contraction.

data.text: During muscle cell shortening, the length of the A bands changes.
What is the role of chemically gated ion channels in the excitation and contraction of skeletal muscle?
data.answer: They create a small local depolarization that triggers voltage-gated ion channels to create an action potential.
choices: They cause a large local depolarization
They open or close in response to changes in membrane potential
They store acetylcholine in synaptic vesicles

data.text: What is temporal summation?
data.answer: An increase in the frequency of stimulation.
choices: An increase in the frequency of stimulation.
An increase in the strength of stimulation.

data.text: As part of a biomechanics study, you learn that the myofilaments in a sarcomere are held in alignment at the Z discs and the M lines and are anchored to the sarcolemma at the Z discs.
What happens during fused or complete tetanus?
data.answer: Muscle relaxation disappears, and contractions become smooth and sustained.
choices: Muscle relaxation disappears, and contractions become smooth and sustained.
The muscle is already partially contracted, and even more calcium is released into the cytosol.
The contractions add together, producing a sustained but quivering contraction.
The second twitch appears to ride on the shoulders of the first.

data.text: What is the main factor that distinguishes aerobic endurance from anaerobic threshold during muscle activity?
Why is muscle fatigue considered a protective mechanism?
What is the ideal length on the length-tension relationship curve for a muscle during an isometric contraction?
data.answer: When the muscle is close to its resting length
choices: When the muscle is fully stretched
When the muscle is maximally compressed
When the muscle is close to its resting length
When the muscle is at its optimal length

data.text: What is disuse atrophy, and how quickly can muscle strength decline under conditions of immobilization?
data.answer: Degeneration and loss of mass due to disuse
choices: Increase in muscle size due to disuse
Degeneration and loss of mass due to disuse
Improvement in muscle tone due to disuse

data.text: In a molecular biology study, you are examining the composition of thick filaments. What is the primary protein found in thick filaments?
What happens during the cross bridge cycle?
data.answer: Myosin heads attach to actin sites and take steps along the thin filament.
choices: Calcium ions are released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum.
Myosin heads attach to actin sites and take steps along the thin filament.
Tropomyosin blocks myosin-binding sites on actin.

data.text: Why does rigor mortis gradually dissipate after its peak?
data.answer: Muscle proteins break down after death.
choices: Muscle proteins break down after death.
Calcium is actively pumped out of the cells.

data.text: During muscle contraction, shortening occurs only if the cross bridges generate enough tension on the thin filaments to exceed the forces that oppose shortening.
What is the overload principle in muscle adaptation?
data.answer: Muscles must be overloaded to increase strength and endurance
choices: Muscles must be underused to gain strength
Muscles adapt only to aerobic exercises
Muscles adapt to any level of activity
Muscles must be overloaded to increase strength and endurance

data.text: What is muscle tension?
data.answer: The force exerted by a contracting muscle on an object.
choices: The force exerted by a contracting muscle on an object.
The opposing force exerted on the muscle by the weight of the object.
The relaxation phase of muscle contraction.

data.text: A person is struggling with regulating fluid passage in their body. Which type of muscle tissue dysfunction might be the cause?
Skeletal muscle contractions are involuntary.
In an examination of muscle elasticity, you learn that elastic filaments provide elastic recoil when tension is released and help maintain myofilament organization.
What functional characteristic makes slow oxidative fibers best suited to endurance-type activities?
What is the result of the events at the neuromuscular junction?
data.answer: A transient change in membrane potential (end plate potential)
choices: A sustained change in membrane potential
A transient change in membrane potential (end plate potential)

data.text: During repolarization, a muscle fiber is in a refractory period and cannot be stimulated again until repolarization is complete.
You are studying the structural organization of skeletal muscle. What is a muscle fiber?
choices: A discrete bundle of muscle cells
A contractile unit composed of myofilaments
A complex organelle composed of bundles of myofilaments

data.text: What restores the ionic conditions of the resting state during repolarization?
What is recruitment in the context of muscle contraction?
data.answer: The process of delivering stimuli of increasing voltage to call more muscle fibers into play.
choices: The process of activating stretch receptors in muscles.
The process of delivering stimuli of increasing voltage to call more muscle fibers into play.
The process of breaking down acetylcholine by acetylcholinesterase.
The process of delivering maximal stimuli to achieve the strongest contraction.

data.text: What is the main disadvantage of the anaerobic glycolysis pathway?
You are investigating the role of thick and thin filaments in muscle contraction. The sliding of the thick filaments past the thin filaments produces muscle shortening.
What happens to the H zones during muscle cell shortening?
In a physiological study, you observe blood vessels branching through the connective tissue sheaths of a skeletal muscle. What is the primary reason for this rich blood supply?
data.answer: To provide oxygen and nutrients to muscle fibers
choices: To provide oxygen and nutrients to muscle fibers
To anchor the muscle to bones
To transmit pulling force to bones

data.text: What is the size principle in muscle recruitment?
data.answer: The principle that smaller, more excitable motor neurons are recruited first.
choices: The principle that larger muscles are recruited first.
The principle that smaller, more excitable motor neurons are recruited first.
The principle that muscle fibers with the smallest diameter are recruited first.
The principle that muscle recruitment is entirely random.

data.text: While studying muscle attachments, you find a connection that involves the fusion of the epimysium of the muscle with the periosteum of a bone. What type of muscle attachment is this?
You are conducting an experiment to study muscle tissue characteristics. What term refers to the ability of a muscle cell to receive and respond to a stimulus by changing its membrane potential?
In a histology examination, you observe a repeating series of dark and light bands along the length of a myofibril. What term describes this banding pattern?
You are examining a muscle fiber's banding patterns. The H zone in the A band appears less dense because the thin filaments do not extend into this region.
Rigor mortis occurs due to the irreversibly cross-linked actin and myosin after death.
You are examining the structural proteins of the myofibril. Dystrophin links the thin filaments to the integral proteins of the sarcolemma.
What are the recognizable changes in skeletal muscles resulting from aerobic or endurance exercise?
data.answer: Increase in capillaries, mitochondria, and myoglobin synthesis
choices: Increase in capillaries, mitochondria, and myoglobin synthesis

data.text: Which pathway provides the majority of ATP during prolonged activities such as marathon runs and bicycle touring?
choices: Direct phosphorylation of ADP by creatine phosphate

data.text: During a routine check-up, a 5-year-old boy is diagnosed with Duchenne muscular dystrophy. At what age is DMD typically diagnosed?
As a researcher examining skeletal muscle, what is the primary function of the epimysium?
choices: Anchors the muscle to the connective tissue covering

data.text: You are investigating muscle elasticity. The connective tissue sheaths contribute significantly to the natural elasticity of muscle tissue.
A patient's heart is contracting steadily, but neural controls allow occasional speed increases. The patient has no conscious control over these fluctuations.
As part of a discussion on treatment options, you learn that there is currently a cure for Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD).
What factor influences the force of muscle contraction by affecting the number of myosin cross bridges attached to actin?
In the sliding filament model of contraction, what is the role of the myosin heads on the thick filaments when muscle fibers are stimulated by the nervous system?
data.answer: Latch onto actin in the thin filaments
choices: Latch onto actin in the thin filaments
Detach from actin in the thin filaments

data.text: What happens to the I bands during muscle cell shortening?
In a biomechanics study, you learn that indirect muscle attachments, such as tendons, are more common due to their durability and small size.
As part of your research on muscle functions, you discover a tissue that can shorten forcibly when adequately stimulated. Which characteristic sets this tissue apart from all other tissue types?
You are examining a patient who has skeletal muscles making continuous tiny adjustments to counteract the downward pull of gravity. This function contributes to maintaining posture and body position.
How long can stored ATP and creatine phosphate support maximum muscle power?
What is excitation-contraction coupling?
data.answer: The sequence of events by which transmission of an action potential along the sarcolemma causes myofilaments to slide.
choices: The sequence of events by which transmission of an action potential along the sarcolemma causes myofilaments to slide.
The direct action of an action potential on myofilaments.
The contraction of muscle fibers without the involvement of action potentials.
The sequence of events leading to muscle relaxation.

data.text: What characteristic is used to classify muscle fibers based on their speed of contraction?
A person's hair stands on end as a physiological response. Which type of muscle is responsible for this reaction?
choices: انا اخوكم في الله ادور زوجة صالحة

data.text: As part of a molecular biology research project, you learn that DMD is caused by a defective gene for dystrophin, a cytoplasmic protein that helps stabilize the sarcolemma.
How does muscle hypertrophy mainly occur?
data.answer: Increased size of individual muscle fibers
choices: Increased size of individual muscle fibers

data.text: Under what circumstances does the anaerobic glycolysis pathway convert pyruvic acid into lactic acid?
data.answer: When blood flow and oxygen delivery are impaired
choices: In the presence of sufficient oxygen
When blood flow and oxygen delivery are impaired

data.text: In a genetic counseling session, a parent asks about the inheritance pattern of Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD). What would be an accurate response?
During a discussion on muscle contraction signaling, you mention that the roles of the T tubules and SR in providing signals for contraction are not interconnected and operate independently.
What is the function of synaptic vesicles in the neuromuscular junction?
As part of a physiology study, you discover that tropomyosin blocks myosin-binding sites on actin in a relaxed muscle fiber.
In a biomechanics study, you learn that titin, the elastic filament, extends from the Z disc to the thick filament and helps the muscle cell spring back into shape after stretching.

While discussing muscle contraction with a colleague, you mention a tubular structure that protrudes into the muscle cell interior, allowing changes in the membrane potential to rapidly penetrate deep into the muscle fiber. What structure are you referring to?
As part of a histology study, you find connective tissue sheaths surrounding a discrete bundle of muscle cells. These sheaths support each cell and reinforce the muscle.
What is the threshold stimulus?
choices: A stimulus that produces no observable contractions.
A stimulus delivered to a completely relaxed muscle.

data.text: As part of a histology examination, you observe a thin filament composed chiefly of which protein?
A drug that interferes with the active transport of calcium ions from the sarcoplasm back into the sarcoplasmic reticulum would result in
In skeletal muscle structure, which of the following surrounds bundles of muscle fibers?
In the case of rigor mortis, after a few hours, skeletal muscles in the whole body will become stiff. What is the background of that mechanism?
choices: All the O2 molecules have appeared in the sarcomeres
All the acetylcholinesterase has been inactivated
The myosin heads will not detach from actin
Acetylcholine vesicles have been released in the motor end-plates
data.answer: The myosin heads will not detach from actin

data.text: What happens when the action potential reaches the nerve ending?
choices: Ca2+ is released outside the muscle cell
Acetylcholine binds to presynaptic neuronal receptors
Acetylcholine is released into the synaptic cleft
Ca2+ is reabsorbed into the sarcoplasmic reticulum
data.answer: Acetylcholine is released into the synaptic cleft

data.text: Which of the following molecules are arranged into a double helix and attached at one end to the Z-line of sarcomere?
The sliding filament model of contraction involves
choices: Actin and myosin sliding past each other and partially overlap
The shortening of thick filaments so that thin filaments slide past
Actin and myosin shortening but not sliding past each other
The Z discs sliding over the myofilaments
data.answer: Actin and myosin sliding past each other and partially overlap

data.text: Which of the following is the characteristic of muscle tone in skeletal muscle?
choices: A state of continuous complete contraction
A state of continuous partial contraction
data.answer: A state of continuous partial contraction

data.text: Which of the following events will occur if a drug blocks release of calcium ions from the sarcoplasmic reticulum to the sarcomere?
Which one of the following is a continuously sustained contraction of muscles that show no relaxation?
Which of the following statements is true about a muscle in an eccentric contraction?
choices: It increases in length and moves the load
It increases in length but does not move the load
It does not change the length and move the load
It decreases in length and moves the load
data.answer: It increases in length but does not move the load

data.text: During cross-bridge cycling of sarcomeres, which of the following steps requires energy in the form of ATP?
choices: Myosin head rotates towards the middle of the sarcomere
Myosin head rotates away from the middle of the sarcomere

data.text: Which disease results in muscle weakness due to a gradual loss of neurotransmitter receptors?
Which of the following ions are necessary for the chemical events for muscle contraction?
Which of the following events happen next when the calcium enters the axon terminal following the arrival of an action potential?
choices: Opening of sodium channels in the muscle

data.text: Which of the following contractions in the skeletal muscle generates the lowest force?
Which of the following movements or ions is associated with rapid depolarization of muscle cells?
Which part of the sarcomere in a contracted muscle decreases in size (or may disappear completely)?
At which of the following portions of myofibril contraction actually occurs?
Which of the following is the correct mechanism by which creatine phosphate produces energy for muscle contraction?
A dead skeletal muscle cannot relax due to which one of the following causes?
choices: All of the calcium has been pumped away
Actin and myosin remain locked together
Due to the development of sustained tetanus
data.answer: Actin and myosin remain locked together

data.text: Which of the following statements is true about muscle tone?
choices: It is due to spinal reflexes
data.answer: It is due to spinal reflexes

data.text: Which of the following effects is noticed when the external load on a skeletal muscle is increased?
A weight-lifter strains to lift a heavy weight and there is no movement of the person's arms holding on to the weight. This type of contraction is called a/an ______ contraction.
Which of the following is the quick jerky contraction of one or more motor units whose stimulus threshold has been reached?
Which of the following sources of energy is slowly available to the muscle during contraction and lasts for hours?
When a muscle is stimulated repeatedly at a high rate, the amount of tension gradually increases to a steady maximum tension. This is called_________.
Which statement best describes the goal of medications used to treat myasthenia gravis?
choices: To increase the number of acetylcholine receptors
To decrease the number of synaptic vesicles
To inhibit Ca2+ release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum
To inhibit the function of cholinesterase
data.answer: To increase the number of acetylcholine receptors

data.text: The region of the sarcomere that contains both actin and myosin myofilaments is called the
Which of the following is a shared characteristic of cardiac and skeletal muscles?
choices: Both cardiac and skeletal muscle fibers are branched

data.text: In a skeletal muscle fiber, the sarcomere is a repetitive unit that consists of the entire region between the:
The endomysium is a delicate connective tissue sheath that surrounds a/an:
Which of the following is the only muscle type that is nonstriated and involuntary?
What is the BEST definition of the origin of a muscle?
choices: The attachment of the muscle to a bone
The proximal attachment of the muscle to a bone
The distal attachment of the muscle to a bone
The attachment of the muscle to a bone that is relatively fixed
data.answer: The attachment of the muscle to a bone that is relatively fixed

data.text: Ahmad is a 2 years old boy with muscle weakness and is diagnosed with Duchene Muscular Dystrophy. What is the most likely cause of his diseases?
choices: Mutation in Y-chromosome leading to absence of dystrophin
Mutation in X-chromosome leading to absence of dystrophin
Mutation in Y-chromosome leading to absence of troponin
Mutation in X-chromosome leading to absence of troponin
data.answer: Mutation in X-chromosome leading to absence of dystrophin

data.text: Fatima is a 25 years old female with muscle weakness and is diagnosed with myasthenia gravis. What is the most likely cause of her muscle weakness?
choices: Reduced calcium entry at the nerve terminal

data.text: When Ali lifts a weight, calcium is released inside his muscle cells. The calcium binds to which part of the sarcomere?
What is true about the skeletal muscle cells?
choices: Each cell contracts individually, and not in groups
They don't contract in a rhythmic manner
Cells are attached to each other through intercalated disks

data.text: What is the cause of rigor mortis?
choices: Breakdown of protein in the cell after death
Diffusion of potassium out of the cell after death
Calcium influx into the sarcoplasm after death
High levels of sodium in the cell after death
data.answer: Calcium influx into the sarcoplasm after death

data.text: While doing resistant exercises in the gym, Ahmed had a sharp pain in his right biceps muscle. On examination, his doctor found a tear in the connective tissue sheath covering his muscle fascicle. What is the name of this sheath?
Which of the following is an elaborate network of membranes in skeletal muscle cells that functions in calcium storage?
What will happen during activities that require aerobic exercise?
choices: Glycogen is the primary source of energy
Most of the muscle's energy is produced in mitochondria
Fatigue occurs in a few minutes
data.answer: Most of the muscle's energy is produced in mitochondria

data.text: Which of the following will help repay the body's oxygen deficit after intense exercise?
What will happen to calcium after nervous stimulation of the muscle cell has stopped?
choices: Is chemically bound to the filaments
Is pumped into the extracellular fluid

data.text: Which of the following is most likely the result if one nerve stimulus arrives at a muscle fiber so soon that the fiber has only partially relaxed from the previous twitch?
Which of the following best describes the event happening to muscle in an isotonic contraction? The muscle…?
choices: Does not change in length but increases tension
Changes in length and moves the load
Rapidly resynthesizes creatine phosphate and ATP
data.answer: Changes in length and moves the load

data.text: Which of the following substances increases in quantity during repetitive muscle contraction?

Aisha decides to pick her pencil and an action potential is generated in her brain. After the action potential arrives at the nerve terminal at her neuromuscular junction, what will be the first change there?
choices: Release of calcium from the muscle sarcoplasmic reticulum
Entry of calcium into the nerve terminal
Interaction of muscle actin and myosin
Release of acetylcholine into the synaptic cleft
data.answer: ntry of calcium into the nerve terminal

data.text: In an isotonic contraction, the muscle:
choices: Does not change in length but increases tension
Rapidly resynthesizes creatine phosphate and ATP
Changes in length and moves the load
data.answer: Changes in length and moves the load

data.text: How would the loss of acetylcholinesterase from the motor end plate affect skeletal muscle?
choices: It would cause spastic paralysis (muscles are contracted and unable to relax).
It would cause flaccid paralysis (muscles are relaxed and unable to contract).
It would have little effect on skeletal muscles.
data.answer: It would cause spastic paralysis (muscles are contracted and unable to relax).

data.text: Fatigued muscle cells that recover rapidly are the products of
Which one of the following statements best describes a muscle motor unit?
choices: One nerve fiber and all the muscle fibers innervated by that nerve
All of the fascicles innervated by several neurons
All of the nerves that unite to make a whole muscle contract
A section of myofibrils from Z lines to Z lines
data.answer: One nerve fiber and all the muscle fibers innervated by that nerve

data.text: Which of the following sentences describe cell excitability:
choices: The ability to receive and respond to a stimulus by changing its membrane potential
The ability of a muscle cell to recoil and resume its resting length after stretching
The ability to shorten forcibly when adequately stimulated
The ability to extend or stretch
data.answer: The ability to receive and respond to a stimulus by changing its membrane potential

data.text: Rigor mortis occurs after death because
choices: Calcium is actively transported back to the sarcoplasmic reticulum.

data.text: The following describes the latent period of muscle twitch
choices: All cross bridges are interacting with actin myofilaments.
Cross bridges begin to cycle but muscle tension is not yet measurable.
Cross bridges are active, from the onset to the peak of tension development.
Is due to pumping of Ca2+ back into the SR; muscle tension decreases to zero.
data.answer: Cross bridges begin to cycle but muscle tension is not yet measurable.

data.text: List the following structures in order from smallest to largest. (1) muscle fiber (2) myofilament (3) myofibril (4) muscle fasciculus
Which of the following statements best describes the cause of myasthenia gravis?
choices: Inhibition of Ca2+ release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum

data.text: Inhibiting the release of acetylcholine at neuromuscular junction will;
choices: Inhibit the permeability of the sarcolemma to Na+
Increases the release of Ca2+ from the sarcoplasmic reticulum

data.text: Which of the following best describes muscle tone?
choices: The condition athletes attain after intensive training
The ability of a muscle to maintain contraction against an outside force
A state of sustained, partial contraction of muscles that is necessary to maintain posture
A feeling of well-being following exercise
data.answer: A state of sustained, partial contraction of muscles that is necessary to maintain posture

data.text: A six-year-old child, who used to be active, started to become clumsy and fall frequently. Doctors diagnosed him as having a sex-linked disease that makes skeletal muscles weaken. His case is most probably:
choices: The ability to extend or stretch

data.text: Fill in the blank. A weight lifter strains to lift a heavy weight and there is no movement of the person’s arms holding on to the weight. This type of contraction is called ________ contraction.
Which type of respiration rapidly produces ATP for short time periods?
choices: Oxidation of molecules within the mitochondria
Both the aerobic and anaerobic respiration

data.text: A patient has drooping of the upper eyelids, difficulty in swallowing and talking, and generalized weakness and fatigability. Which of the following diseases has the mentioned features?
choices: Paralysis of all muscles in the body

data.text: Which statement is true about Duchenne's muscular dystrophy?
choices: Muscles are wasted and replaced by only fat tissue
The muscles are acetylcholine receptor deficient
Patients have X and Y-linked recessive inheritance pattern
Muscles lack a protein called dystrophin
data.answer: Muscles lack a protein called dystrophin

data.text: Which of the following bands gives the skeletal muscle a striated appearance?
Which of the following movements of ions is associated with rapid depolarization of muscle cells?
Which of the following does NOT occur during skeletal muscle contraction?
choices: Calcium concentration in the sarcoplasmic reticulum increases.

data.text: Which of the following is the correct order for the phases of a muscle twitch?
All of the following are correct for 'muscle fatigue' EXCEPT:
choices: Serves to prevent complete depletion of ATP in muscle, which would result in death of muscle cells and rigor mortis.
Ionic imbalances reduce the size of the action potential, which reduces the amount of Ca2+ released from the SR.
A state of physiological inability to contract even though the muscle is still receiving stimuli.
Lactic acid is a major cause of fatigue that raises the concentration of H+ and alters contractile proteins.
data.answer: Lactic acid is a major cause of fatigue that raises the concentration of H+ and alters contractile proteins.

data.text: What will happen first when an action potential reaches a nerve terminal?
Which of the following describes the region of the sarcomere that contains both actin and myosin myofilaments?
Mohammed's 3-mile run every morning takes about 30 minutes. Which of these sources provides most of the energy for his run?
The correct order for the smallest to the largest unit of organization in muscle tissue is
Which organelles do you expect to find in abundance in skeletal muscle cell?
Which one of the following statements would represent incomplete tetanus?
choices: Long rest period before contractions start
Multiple contractions followed by a long rest period

data.text: H zone is present in the central region of the sarcomere and light in color. When contraction occurs this light zone disappears because the
choices: actin and myosin filaments are completely overlapped
shortening of the sarcomere causes stretching of H zone
actin filaments don't extend to the middle of the sarcomere
troponin C uncovers the actin and myosin filaments
data.answer: actin and myosin filaments are completely overlapped

data.text: Which of the following is true about skeletal muscle?
choices: Sensory neurons stimulate muscles to contract.
There are very few blood vessels in skeletal muscle.
Every muscle fiber receives a branch of an axon.
There are very few nerve fibers in a muscle.
data.answer: Every muscle fiber receives a branch of an axon.

data.text: An isotonic contraction is characterized by?
choices: Change in length and increased tension
Change in length and lifting of load
Rapid syntheses of creatine phosphate and ATP
No conversion of pyruvate to lactate
data.answer: Change in length and lifting of load

data.text: The most important factor in decreasing the intracellular concentration of calcium ion after contraction is
choices: Diffusion of calcium out of the cell.
Active transport of calcium across the sarcolemma.
Active transport of calcium into the sarcoplasmic reticulum.
Diffusion of calcium into the sarcoplasmic reticulum.
data.answer: Active transport of calcium into the sarcoplasmic reticulum.

data.text: A fascicle
choices: Is a bundle of reticular fibers.
Is a bundle of collagen fibers.
Is only found in smooth muscle.

data.text: Hypertrophy of skeletal muscles from weight lifting is caused by an increase in the
Which of the following conditions apply to a muscle when it is stimulated repeatedly at a high rate and the amount of tension gradually increases to a steady maximum tension?
A person is carrying a heavy item and there is no movement of his arms, while holding on to the weight. This type of contraction is called _______ contraction.
The repeating functional unit of a skeletal muscle fiber is the
Which of the following is a property of a muscle that mostly contains slow oxidative fibers?
